Adam Smith and liberalized markets Adam Smith believed landowners should govern society because they had a stake in their country by virtue of owning real estate, and he therefore believed they made better decisions than what he considered to be ruthless industrialists who would skew government policy in favor of benefiting their sectional interests at the expense of the poor. In order to counteract the effects of industrialization on the human condition, which he described as creating a “race of laborers” whose humanity was crushed, he called for widespread public education. In the context of 18th century Europe this was a very radical idea. Smith generally opposed government intervention in market transactions on the grounds that government was not a neutral representative of the public (the concept of the “public good” wasn’t well developed at this point in history) and would almost always favor vested aristocratic or business interests and interfere with what be believed was humanity’s natural propensity to trade. His advocacy of what later came to be called “free markets” was based on a recognition of the economic fallacies underpinning mercantilism and the belief that free markets would generate liberty and equality by removing the influences of the upper classes, particularly with respect to price-fixing. The result would be a natural order of liberty where people interacted with each other as equals in the marketplace. Smith wrote his magnum opus An Inquiry into the Wealth of Nations in an earlier phase of industrialization where the main object of criticism was the economic thinking that dominated Europe since the commercial revolution. His analysis of market relations revolved around product markets in the context of individual producers exchanging their wares through a process of mutual negotiation. In these scenarios it is easy to see liberty and equality in market relations, but he gave scant attention to the suppression of individual agency and autonomy resulting from labor markets and the power dynamics they generate and reinforce.  Karl Marx and socialism Karl Marx is completely different in that he rejects any notion of a just or moral society as an idealistic bourgeois notion that relies upon subjective value judgements rather than an analysis of concrete material conditions. Marx’s objective was understanding the dynamics of capitalism and taking them to their logical conclusion; thus socialism is not a prescriptive ideal but merely the result of an analysis of capitalism’s laws of motion as well as a more general historical framework where technological development is the prime mover of socioeconomic development. Socialism isn’t a “just” system and Marx vigorously condemned early socialist thinkers interested in projecting their subjective notions of morality and organizing movements to achieve said ideals, which he and later socialists lambasted as “Utopian socialists”. Marx’s views are postulated on the historical trend of technological development freeing humans from mundane activities necessary for bare survival to focus on more complex tasks and human needs through increasing productivity. In the Marxist framework, once technological development reaches a certain point it renders existing social relationships insufficient for further progress, creating a contradiction between what is technologically feasible and the old stifling forms of social organization. To simplify greatly, Marx saw that economic activity was becoming increasingly socialized and capital inputs were becoming an ever larger composition in the production of economic value relative to human labor. As constant capital - the means of production - became an ever larger component in the production of economic value, their returns increase while labor’s share decreases. Eventually development would reach a point where shared ownership of the means of production is necessitated to provide the entire society with a source of income (this need not take the form of money and can take the form of labor vouchers or in-kind allotments), thereby coming full circle by socializing the return on the means of production. Eventually technological development reaches a point where human labor plays a marginal role in the production of value, leading to a state where labor is reduced to a bare minimum and people are truly free to pursue their own interests. This would eliminate social hierarchy and inequality because everyone would have an equal relationship to the social means of production and could no longer be easily compelled to submit to any other individual; it would also engender genuine freedom where people’s lives are defined by their own interests, passions and desires as opposed to being forced to work as a prerequisite for receiving material necessities. While this might sound like a paradise from the perspective of a worker living in a capitalist society, it is not intended to be any form of ideal society nor is it presented as being a morally just social arrangement - it is merely the result of technological progress and socioeconomic evolution. To put it in perspective, to an average European living in the 18th century, early-21st century Europe for the average European would appear to be a utopia with its productivity, life expectancy, and widespread of material necessities now taken for granted. Karl Marx believed the working class would be the agent of social change required for the socialization of the means of production. Keeping in line with his materialist outlook, this had nothing to do with moral outrage over the treatment of workers or their living conditions under capitalism, it simply had to do with the material interests of different classes. Marx assumed that people are primarily driven by material interests rather than ideals. Logically, the capitalist class as the ruling class under capitalism wouldn’t be interested in abdicating their ownership of the means of production and losing their social prestige, power and wealth during the transition to socialism. The working class, on the other hand, would stand to benefit most from the transition to socialism. Hence the slogan “workers of the world unite, you have nothing to lose but your chains!”. Marx is not interested in a “just”’society. He views talk of justice as bourgeois ideology. His central values are freedom and self-realization. I’ve read Smith’s Theory of the Moral Sentiments long ago but I don’t recall if he said anything what makes a just society or what he says if he does.
